section.title: Secant Line to a Curve
section.p: One of the building blocks in differential calculus is the secant line to a curve. The only requirement for a line to be considered a secant line to a curve is that the line must intersect the curve in at least two points.
In , we see a secant line to the curve y=\fe{f}{x} through the points \point{0}{3} and \point{4}{-5}. Verify that the slope of this line is -2.

sidebyside.p: The formula for f is \fe{f}{x}=3+2x-x^2. We can use this formula to come up with a generalized formula for the slope of secant lines to this curve. Specifically, the slope of the line connecting the point \point{x_0}{\fe{f}{x_0}} to the point \point{x_1}{\fe{f}{x_1}} is derived in the following example.
